docs.title: 1. What Is Java and Why Install It?
docs.text:
Java is a widely used programming language and runtime environment. Many tools and services (Hadoop, Hive, Elasticsearch, Jenkins, etc.) require Java to run.

On Linux, Java usually means installing a JDK (Java Development Kit), which includes:

  • JRE (Java Runtime Environment)
  • Compiler (javac)
  • Useful development tools

docs.title: 2. Check If Java Is Already Installed
Possible results:
docs.text:
• Java is installed → version information is shown
  • Java is not installed → command not found

If Java is missing or the version is not what you want, continue below.

docs.title: 3. Choose Which Java Version to Install
docs.text:
For beginners, OpenJDK is strongly recommended:

  • Free and open source
  • Officially supported on CentOS
  • Stable and widely used

Common choices:

Java Version Recommended For Java 8 (1.8) Legacy systems, Hadoop ecosystem Java 11 Long-Term Support (LTS) Java 17 Newer LTS (if system supports it)

👉 If you are unsure, Java 8 or Java 11 is a safe choice.

docs.title: 5.1 List Available Java Versions
docs.text:
sudo yum search openjdk

You’ll see packages like:

  • java-1.8.0-openjdk
  • java-11-openjdk
  • java-17-openjdk

docs.title: 5.2 Install Java 8 (Example)
docs.text:
sudo yum install -y java-1.8.0-openjdk java-1.8.0-openjdk-devel

Explanation:

  • openjdk → runtime
  • openjdk-devel → compiler (javac) and development tools

docs.title: 6. Verify Java Installation
docs.text:
After installation:

java -version

Expected output example:

openjdk version "1.8.0_392"
OpenJDK Runtime Environment
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM

Check the compiler:

javac -version

docs.title: 7. Manage Multiple Java Versions (Optional but Important)
docs.text:
If multiple Java versions are installed:

sudo alternatives --config java

You’ll see something like:

There are 2 programs which provide 'java'.

1 /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk/bin/java
2 /usr/lib/jvm/java-11-openjdk/bin/java

Enter the number you want to use and press Enter.

docs.title: 8.2 Set JAVA_HOME (System-Wide)
docs.text:
Edit /etc/profile:

sudo vi /etc/profile

Add at the end:

export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk
export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

Apply changes:

source /etc/profile

Verify:

echo $JAVA_HOME

docs.title: 9. Test Java with a Simple Program (Optional)
docs.text:
Create a test file:

vi HelloWorld.java

Paste:

public class HelloWorld {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello, Java on CentOS!");
    }
}

Compile and run:

javac HelloWorld.java
java HelloWorld

Output:

Hello, Java on CentOS!

🎉 Java is working!

docs.title: ❌ java: command not found
docs.text:
• Java is not installed
  • Or PATH is not configured correctly

docs.title: 11. Summary
docs.text:
• Use OpenJDK on CentOS
  • Install via yum (simple and safe)
  • Verify with java -version
  • Set JAVA_HOME for compatibility
  • Java 8 / 11 are best for beginners
